text: JUDGE GOINES turns to the Jury FOREMAN.
Mister Foreman, have you arrived at a verdict?
We have, your honor.  We find the defendant guilty of all the charges.
Forty, rumpled, cheap suit, cheap haircut.  He reacts, tu to the jury, indignant. His attorney, DONNA O'DAY, rises.  She's twenty-four, loo younger.

Your honor, may I approach the bench? As BERNIE fumes, the JUDGE, DONNA and the youthful clean- PROSECUTOR engage in an earnest, inaudible discussion. Frustrated, Bernie is watching them when he notices somet that distracts him from his anguish. Donna's wallet is lying in her open attache case.  The op of the case screens the wallet from the view of the JURY, JUDGE, COURT REPORTERS, etc. Bernie looks around, checking the spectators section. No spectators.
Bernie gets the wallet to his lap.  In between cautious g toward the bench where the conference continues inaudibly surreptitiously selects some of the twenties and some of tens from the wallet.
The conference breaks up, DONNA heads back toward the def table. The wallet still concealed in his lap under the table, BE is indignant.
What's going on?  "Guilty"!  What is this?
I got your bail continued.
Bail, for Chrissake!  I'm innocent! The JUDGE gavels for order as BERNIE slips DONNA's "light wallet back into her attache case unseen.

Mister LaPlante, I have been persuaded in view of your continued employment and your lack of prior convictions, to continue your bail under the same conditions heretofore, pending sentencing six days from now.  In the meantime you will make an appointment with the probation officer who will make a recommendation to me regarding your sentence.  I urge you to use these six days to set your personal affairs in order in anticipation of incarceration.
BERNIE and DONNA are hurrying along the crowded corridor the courtroom.
"Anticipation of incarceration"?
(upset)
He means prison, Mr. LaPlante.

I know what he means.  I'm not a prison kinda guy, Miss O'Day.  I'm a goddamn working man for Chrissake!  Maybe I "augment" my income a little with some "business deals," maybe summa the guys I sell to are crooks, how would I know, I'm not an investigator.  You can't make it on a wage no more, not in this country.
I think our best course right now would be to focus on the Probation Officer's report...
He gives a good report and I walk?
We can hope. (consulting her notes)
You still have your job, right?
Yeah, I been calling in sick.  They think I got the flu.
And a son by your ex-wife?  Joseph.
A son, yeah.  What about him?  Joey.
Are you pretty involved in his upbringing?
Involved!  Christ!  She attached my goddamn paycheck!  Child support. Why do you think I can't afford a lawyer? (then...)
You know what I mean.  Why I got a court appointed lawyer instead of a, uh, more experienced...
I understand.  How often do you see your son?
Often, uh.
How recently?
Uh, his birthday, uh, May.  I think.
It's November.
(beat... beat... beat...)
She don't like me to see him. Says I'm a bad influence.

I think you should visit your son. And try and get your boss to write a note about your performance on the job.  You need to create the impression of a responsible, decent citizen with familial responsibilities who happened to slip up once. They have reached the front door.  BERNIE nods, about to
(with difficulty)
Uh, I know you're having financial difficulties, Mister LaPlante, but I wonder if... I mean, the money I loaned you...
Some of it.  Right here.  I got some of it.  I'll get the rest as soon as I can. BERNIE pulls out the crumpled bills he took from Donna's and hands them to her.
(surprised and touched)
I know things are difficult for you, Mister LaPlante.  I don't want to take your last dime... BERNIE is already reaching for a twenty.
Right.  I better keep some if I'm gonna see the kid.  For gas and stuff. Then, unable to resist the chance, he snatches another.

A LION lies glumly in his cage, staring balefully through bars at BERNIE who stares balefully back, contemplating t bars.  At BERNIE'S side is a ten year old boy, JOEY, whos scrubbed appearance is in sharp contrast to BERNIE'S rump slightly soiled look.
Wow!  Look at that one! JOEY is indicating the next cage where a BLACK PANTHER is restlessly to and fro.
If you were in there, he'd kill you, wouldn't he...Dad? As Bernie looks at the PANTHER, the muscular beast looks into BERNIE'S eyes with the furious yellow stare as if to "I'm waiting."
Yeah, yeah, something like that.
BERNIE and JOEY facing each other in a booth, eating burg
This guy, this "friend" your mother's seeing, he's a fireman, huh?  He ever... spend the night, whatsisname?
Sometimes.  His name's Elliot.  He saved a guy's life one time.  In a fire.
Oh yeah?  A hero, huh? (a beat, then...)
Was he in the 'Nam, this guy Elliot?
"The Nomm"?  What's that?
It was this war.  Viet Nam.  Doesn't matter.
Were you in it?  In the war?
You never saw that picture, huh?
What picture?
Me in my uniform.  Used to be on the bookcase.
Deserted except for BERNIE and JOEY side by side at the u BERNIE glances at JOEY.

Whatcha gotta do there, buddy, is ya gotta get in close so ya don't piss on yer shoes. It don't matter now cause you're wearin' them sneakers but the time's gonna come when you're gonna be wearin' good shoes, expensive ones, and you don't wanna piss on them, you wanna protect 'em.  From piss, from tough guys, from everything. -- ALTERNATE VERSION --

What I don't like about public restrooms is how you're always standing in piss.  It don't matter to you, you got those sneakers but I'm standing in piss in very expensive shoes.  It's a breakdown in custodial services. JOEY steals a glance at BERNIE, sees him "shake it off" a up.  JOEY does likewise.
Are you gonna take me somewhere next weekend?
I'm working on that.  It's just I got some business problems and... whatsa matter? JOEY is heading for one of the stalls.  He reaches undern and pulls out a wallet.
Somebody lost a wallet. BERNIE is extremely interested, takes the wallet JOEY hol and glances inside. Cash.  A couple of fifties.
BERNIE and JOEY exit the Men's Room and head for the door the parking lot, BERNIE explaining...

You give it to the manager, he pockets the dough, throws the wallet away.  Most people who work in supervisory positions... I'm not saying all... are crooks. JOEY casts a hasty glance at TEENAGER who's wearing the Manager Badge.  The youth could not look more innocent if wore a halo.
A BAG LADY pushing two shopping carts through the parking spots BERNIE and JOEY crossing her path...
Excuse me, sir, could you spare...?
No way, lady, not a chance. BERNIE hurries past her, notices JOEY looking back at the miserable woman.

You gotta resist the urge to be nice to those people, they're con artists, they take advantage of the soft heart.  A lot of 'em are financially better off than the rest of us. Arriving at an ancient, battered Toyota, BERNIE searches his keys and then fusses with the lock.

What I'm gonna do on this wallet thing is, Monday, day after tomorrow, I'm gonna have my secretary phone this guy up from the name on his driver's license Let the guy come and get his wallet and make sure you get a reward. You deserve a reward.  You want one, doncha?  A reward?  Gwan, get in.
BERNIE is at the wheel, the car is gasping, struggling.

Whatcha gotta do, you gotta look out for number one.  It sounds harsh, but it's a goddamn (excuse the vulgarity) jungle out there, kid.  That's why you gotta keep a low profile!  Right?  A low profile! It's where you don't give nobody nothin' to shoot at, stay outta sight, be parta the woodwork, don't ever tell 'em your name, they'll use it against you. JOEY is looking for the right exit sign.  He spots it.
Here.  Get off here.
(a look at Joey)
Thanks.  Thanks, pal. JOEY looks pleased.
BERNIE is turning onto a suburban street, checking the ho
Listen, buddy, I'm really enjoying this relationship we got going here. I been missing out on not knowing you better.  Thing is, I got all this business stuff...
I could go to a movie Thursday night.  'Cause we don't have school on Friday. BERNIE pulls the car up in front of a single story two be house.

Here we are.  Yeah, that's a possibility.  A movie.  Now you gwan in, tell your mother I got you back on time.  Point that out to her. She was always on my case for stuff like that.  She's still like that, right?
(a little grin, his first)
Yeah. (getting out)
I'll see ya... dad. JOEY gets out and runs toward the house.  BERNIE watches go.  Then he pulls out the wallet, thumbs the cash, glanc the credit cards.
The bored, fiftyish bartender, CHICK, is watching the TV over the bar in this unfashionable, nearly-deserted joint looks up when the door opens.
Bernie!  Where ya been, Pal? Arriving at the bar, BERNIE surveys the dimly lit room, c the booths and tables for customers.  Not many.
Some guys been looking for me, Chick?  Spanish kinda guys.
Spanish kinda guys!
Business thing.  Gimme a seven and seven, willya? BERNIE checks his watch, takes a seat, puts a twenty on t
What is it, five days now I don't see you!

'Cause I'm up to my ass in shit is why.  I'm broke, plus I got legal problems... Nobody was asking for me, huh? BERNIE looks around nervously, peering into the shadowy b and rear tables as CHICK puts a drink in front of him.
Nope.  Legal problems, you gotta have a good attorney.
My attorney, she's just outta law school, about a couple of years older than my kid, for Chrissake.
You gotta kid?  How old's your kid?
Nine.  I think.  Maybe ten.  Yeah, ten.  Nice kid.
You got a ten year old attorney, Bernie?
I can't afford no better.  My ex, she attached my pay check for child support payments. (turning)
You looking for Bernie LaPlante by any chance? A MAN who's just entered the lounge shakes his head no an for a table where he's greeted by the COCKTAIL WAITRESS.
I didn't even know you had a kid.
(thoughtful)
The thing about kids is, they're so... young!  They don't know nothin' yet.  When you're a kid, you think you're gonna grow up an' be a "wonderful person" instead of an asshole, like everybody else.
We're all assholes, Bernie?
(ignoring him)
When I was a kid, I thought I was gonna be this fantastic wonderful heroic human being.
You Bernie Planta? BERNIE turns. Two Latinos are right behind him, low lifes, ESPINOSA and VARGAS.
LaPlante.  Bernie LaPlante.  You the guys Bunny called, huh?
Credit cards are being inspected.  ESPINOSA, seated betwe VARGAS and BERNIE, in a booth in the nearly deserted loun looks the cards over dubiously.
Three hours is old, man.  Very old.
Hey, he might not of reported 'em at all yet.  He might not know for a couple hours.
You pick his pocket?
Yeah, more or less.  Trust me, these are very very fresh.

JEFFREY BROADMAN is standing against the granite facade o downtown office building.  Three thousand dollar suit, He tie, expensively cut silver grey hair ruffling slightly i breeze.  Charming smile, candid eyes...

To be honest, I can't make sense of it either, Ms. Gayley. Things seem to be on the upswing, our differences with the SEC have been favorably resolved.  In a business sense, I believe we've "turned the corner..." GALE GAYLEY, a TV reporter, is standing close to BROADMAN microphone in her hand.  She's thirty, attractive, dignif We can hear SIRENS in the distance and, closer, the CRACK of radios and walkie talkies.
Mister Broadman, your wife and children are on their way here as we speak.  Don't you think -- ?

I feel I've done very well in life: good health, wonderful family, much wealth.  I guess what we're talking about here is a kind of despair.  I just have the feeling that everything from here on is going to be... downhill... At a time like this, I think I'm entitled, as the saying goes, to "look out for number one" and put my own needs first.  That pretty much concludes what I have to say. Thanks for coming out here to let me talk to you and your viewers. A nice smile as he drops RIGHT OUT THE BOTTOM OF THE FRAM
Looking down, horrified.
Oh my god!  Chucky, tilt down. Her cameraman, CHUCKY, twenty-five, is already urgently t his vidpak as WE REVEAL that he and GALE are standing on many stories above the street.
Did you get it? (then, doubly horrified)
Jesus, did I say that?
Yeah, I got it.  Sports training. You learn to follow the ball. (looking up at Gale)
How about you do a wrap-up from up here?  I'll pan off that skyscraper over there, find you here, then reveal the drop. GALE looks shaken.

head_text.subj: TV IMAGE, (EXT. OFFICE BUILDING LEDGE - DAY)

text: Later, the CAMERA "finds" GALE in mid-sentence standing o ledge, "wearing" her broadcast voice and persona...
(into mike)

Suicide number 137 of this year in this city was neither a destitute nor a lonely man, but a successful executive with a loving family and forty million dollars in the bank.  If there's nameless "despair" in executive offices, what can there be sixty stories below where the hungry and the homeless, the brutalized and the addicted, fight their daily battle for survival. (beat)
From a ledge sixty stories above the street, I'm Gale Gayley for Channel Four News.
DEAKINS, fifty, shirtsleeves, News Director, and WALLACE, Station Manager, suit and tie, patrician, are watching th monitor while CHUCKY and PARKER, the boyish gofer, hover them.
Whadja think of the fall shot, Chief?  The guy drops twenty stories in perfect focus, center frame while I go smoothly from F16 to F5.6.
Helluva shot, Chucky, beautiful. (pulling out the video tape)
Parker, run this down to Frazier, tell him we open with it at six, eleven and at seven a.m.... PARKER is already running out the door as Gale enters.
Hi, Chief.  You like the suicide?
Never reach out!
Hello, Mister Wallace.
(to Gale)
He's right.  It's unprofessional.
(to Gale)
If you reach out, you could get pulled over yourself.
What're we talking about?  Reach out for what?
I told them how you were upset we didn't save the guy...
Saving people is not our job.  It's as wrong to step in and save someone as it would be to push someone off.
You wouldn't push the guy, would you?
I didn't say I thought we should have saved him..
You didn't?
I said I wished it had at least occurred to me to consider saving him.
What good would that do? GALE sits on Deakins' desk.
It would make me feel like a human being instead of a cynical, hardbitten newswoman.  Besides it wouldn't be a bad story, would it, "Newswoman Saves Suicide?"
Unprofessional.
You just can't bear the idea of good news.
You're sitting on your ticket. GALE finds an envelope on the desk under her butt.
Ticket!  What's going on?
She's flying to New York.  She's been nominated for a Silver Mike...
A Silver Mike!  You're covering us in glory!
I haven't won it yet. (studying ticket, to Deakins)
I notice you've got me scheduled on a flight back an hour after the ceremony.
An hour after...!  Deak, for Heaven's sake!  Let's give her a night in New York City.  We'll put her and her boyfriend up at a good hotel...
She broke up with her boyfriend. (to Gale)
Listen, babe, we needja back. You gotta follow up on the jumper, find the human interest in the grim, unending tale of woe that pours from the wounded heart of the heartless metropolis.
The story behind the story, the ugly scandal behind the falling millionaire, the dirt, you mean.
That too.
(to Wallace)
Would the station put me up at a good hotel...?
(a look toward Deakins)
Absolutely! GALE gives DEAKINS a big grin and starts out.
Okay, hell with it.  Party hearty... is that what they say?  I'll figure something out. (once she's gone)
She's just pretending she's a person.  She's really a reporter. Fifty bucks she's on the first flight back.
You know what I don't get?  I don't get why a guy who's gonna jump asks to talk to a TV reporter?
Cause how's he gonna know he's jumped if it's not on the six o'clock news.

HORNS BLARE as a FORD VAN cuts off a CAB and squirms into parking place marked "HANDICAPPED ONLY." The side of the van reads GUMLEY'S SUPER CARPET CARE and features a cartoon logo and a phone number. BERNIE, wearing Gumley overalls, jumps out of the van and hurries up the steps to an imposing municipal building.
A door reads "PROBATION DEPARTMENT."  MOVE IN ON THE DOOR
Bernie is sitting across the desk from the stone-faced, b Probation Officer, PATRICK DUKE.
(agitated)
Hey!  Do I have a record?  Have I ever done time?  I mean I been arrested a few times, who hasn't? Parking tickets for Chrissake! Suspicion of stuff!  Have I ever been convicted of anything?
Mister LaPlante...

Take a look at my employment record, you got my employment record there, right?  You see any unemployment there, any welfare? I'm a taxpayer.  They eat me alive, the tax people, they got taxes on everything, taxes, taxes, taxes, and forms!  Taxes and forms so I can pay your goddamn salary, so you can sit there and write stuff, guys like me pay your wages...
Mister LaPlante...
Do I hit anybody?  You see me shoot anybody?  Hey, drugs!  Do I sell drugs?  Jesus, I don't belong in prison.  I'm a family man.
Mister LaPlante...

Look, I got this kid.  We got a goddamn relationship!  I'm takin' him to a movie tonight!  He worships me.  If I go down what's this do to my son?  I'm his goddamn role model for Christ sake! DUKE looks up at the "family man's" plaintive look.  Then Bernie ruins it.

Listen, if I coulda afforded an experienced attorney, I woulda walked.  It was a shitty case, very circumstantial.  You gonna send me downstate for having an inexperienced lawyer?  How you gonna feel about the system if you do that? The brief flash of mercy is gone from DUKE'S eyes, replac with a hard glitter.  BERNIE has just shot himself in the foot.

VIGOROUS APPLAUSE!  GALE has just received the Silver Mik Award, a tastefully small, mike-sized replica of a microp from the MASTER OF CEREMONIES.  Clutching it, she faces t applauding AUDIENCE across a podium, speaking into a real microphone.

Thank you, very much.  I'm grateful for this.  Since you're all colleagues here, you know what kind of a team it takes... to put a story on a screen.  I don't have to explain to you how much the cameraman, the editor, the assignment editor and the news director, to mention a few did to get me this award. GALE pauses.  She reaches into her purse and pulls out an She holds it up.
This is an onion. (dramatic pause, then...)

It's a metaphor for a news story. Only a few hours ago I was standing on a ledge sixty stories above a street interviewing a man who subsequently jumped to his death. Forty million dollars in the bank, happily married, good health.  Great story! The AUDIENCE is attentive, mesmerized as they watch her r the outer skin of the onion and toss it dramatically asid
(continuing)
There's gotta be more.  We're pros, right?  Some kinda extramarital hanky panky, maybe?  Another good story! (she peels another layer of onion)
Maybe the guy's been accused of child molesting.  Terrific story! (she peels more off the onion)
Then it turns out the accusation was false.  Wonderful!  More story. The AUDIENCE watches, captivated as the onion gets smalle
(continuing)
Maybe the alleged mistress was lying, setting the guy up. Sensational story! (the onion is very small)
We keep going, keep digging, keep investigating.  We expose the guy's whole life, his family. Why?  Because we're pros! Because... (she pauses dramatically)
we're looking for the truth! GALE considers the tiny remains of the onion in her hand. Then, she peels it down to nothing and lets it fall.

But what if, after all our digging, after all our painstaking investigation, what if it turns out there wasn't any truth?  Just  stories!  One story after another, one layer, then another layer, until there's nothing left.  And if it's like that, do we have any. obligation to stop at any point? Or do we just keep going, digging, digging, digging, peeling, peeling, peeling, until we've peeled it all away, until we've destroyed what we were investigating in the first place?
attentive, as GALE pauses dramatically, then...

I'll bet all of you, like me, yearn for just one story that isn't about uncovering layer after layer of human weakness; a story that reveals with each new layer of investigation, something finer and nobler, something even... inspirational. GALE gazes soberly across the podium at the AUDIENCE.

head_text.subj: TELEVISION IMAGE, (EXT. SKID ROW STREETS - DAY)

text: A BAG LADY addresses the camera, a news interview.
First rule out here on the streets is you gotta watch out for number one.  If you go down... break a bone or something... you're gone! Nobody's gonna pick you up.'
Shitty color!  Looka the skin tones.
WINSTON, fifty and fat, is scowling at the image on the T screen in BERNIE'S spartan and tasteless three room apart BERNIE grabs the remote from WINSTON'S pudgy hands.
Chrissake!  Homeless people are supposed to have shitty skin tones. Look! BERNIE points the remote at the screen...
CLICK!  A gunfight replaces the BAG LADY ON SCREEN, then sitcom, an old movie, MTV, and finally a slick commercial featuring a sexy bikinied BLONDE.

There you go!  Skin tones!  Listen, you gotta fish or cut bait.  I wouldn't even do this if I didn't have these legal problems.  Two fifty.  That's it.  I gotta get outta here, I gotta take my kid to the movies tonight, I'm late. WINSTON stares at the lithe thighs ON THE SCREEN as BERNI starts rummaging urgently in his closet.
I'll go two hundred. BERNIE has just found his good shoes, notices a carton of new jackets.
Two hundred!  How about a jacket? Wanna buy me a jacket?

The engines drone as we look into the sparsely populated cabin of the "baby Boeing".  Among the many empty seats, FLETCHER reads a magazine while his ten year son RICHIE p a pocket video game. LESLIE SUGAR, one of the two Flight Attendants, is servin drink to Mr. Smith, a businessman while FREDDY, the other Attendant, is giving a pillow to an ELDERLY WOMAN. We DISCOVER GALE, cradling a phone to her ear while she awkwardly fishes in her purse and pulls out the Silver Mi Award.
It's very nice actually. (reading the  inscription)

"For Excellence in the Pursuit of Truth."  Uh, listen, I just wanted you to know I got a seat back on the early flight after all so... What? Reacting to what she hears on the phone, GALE overturns t purse in her lap and the contents -- wallet, comb, lipsti notepad, etc. -- spill on the floor.
What do you mean you gave it to Conklin?  Conklin wasn't on that ledge!  Conklin wasn't...
DEAKINS is grinning into his phone, winking at WALLACE wh standing beside his desk.

Gale, you were gonna do the town, remember?  Fancy suite at the station's expense, see a show, get laid maybe.  What was I supposed to do? Still grinning, he breaks off and listens to Gale's faint audible response while holding out his palm to WALLACE in triumphant "pay me" gesture.  Then he speaks into the pho

Okay, okay, you get back tonight, doll, and I'll take Conklin off your suicide.  Fly carefully... and congratulations on the award. DEAKINS hangs up and smugly pockets the fifty WALLACE has from his wallet, chuckling gleefully...
What'd I tell ya!  They're all like that, the good ones.  They're junkies for the story.  They can't let go.
The eight-year-old, KELLY, seated next to GALE is helping pick up the contents of her purse from the floor.
Thank you.  Very much. KELLY beams.  And GALE gives a look to KELLY'S mother SUS who's seated on the other side of KELLY.
There's another credit card on the floor. GALE reaches down to pick up her Visa card from the floor
Thanks. GALE inserts the Visa Card in her wallet with the other c
Rain comes down in curtains as BERNIE'S Toyota chugs and through curtains of water.
BERNIE is at the wheel, trying to see through the rain sw windshield.  He's talking to himself as he drives...
I know why it's raining.  I coulda predicted this.  It's raining because my wipers are fucked up. If my wipers were okay, the fucking sun would be shining right now. At night!

Engines DRONE monotonously.  The Flight Engineer is looki magazine while the PILOT and CO-PILOT, surrounded by glow instruments, stare into the blackness ahead... until some catches the bored PILOT'S eye.  A red light on the contro panel.  He frowns and looks closer.
Looking for exit signs, BERNIE can barely see through the of rain that his malfunctioning wipers do little to clear Suddenly a sign looms into view and disappears before he read it.
Damn!

The engines drone.  The cabin is peaceful, most PASSENGER dozing or talking softly as GALE glances up from her maga sees SUSAN reading while KELLY sleeps peacefully, her hea SUSAN'S lap. PING!  The electronic tone.  Gale looks up, sees the "Fas Seat Belt" sign illuminated. GALE looks toward the dark window.  No sign of any lights No city.  No airport.  strange. The P.A. SYSTEM comes to life and the CAPTAIN'S mellifluo VOICE murmurs soothingly...

Ladies and Gentlemen, this is your Captain.  We're experiencing a high reading on one of our indicators. Ten to one, it's a malfunction in a gauge, but just as a precaution I'm going to ask you to fasten your seat belts while the Flight Attendants run through some safety procedures with you.  I apologize for the necessity and the inconvenience. Murmurs in the cabin.  What does this mean?  SUSAN looks question at GALE, puzzled as Flight Attendants LESLIE and take their positions to demonstrate safety procedures.
First make sure your seat belts are fastened securely.  Then brace your arms against the seat ahead at you like this.  You can use pillows or blankets...
(waking up)
Mommy, what's going on?
Everything's going to be fine, honey. GALE'S eyes meet SUSAN'S eyes.  Fear.  Brave smile.

Pulling off the freeway, BERNIE peers at the signs that g him as he slows to a stop at the foot of the exit. Unable to read them through the windshield he has to open door and stand in the rain. Even then, the sign is obscured by torrents of rain.
All eyes are on LESLIE as she continues her instructions.

-- when you reach the bottom of the chute you should immediately move as far away from the plane as possible in the event of a fire on the aircraft. Glancing around, GALE glimpses pale, strained FACES. She sees the ELDERLY WOMAN holding the arm of a man, her She sees a MRS. BROWN squeezing a MR. BROWN'S hand tightl Looking back down the aisle she sees MR. FLETCHER putting arm around RICHIE'S shoulder, father and son united again fate. Beside her she sees SUSAN trying to comfort KELLY.
Those of you who can should help others who may be unable to move quickly. GALE is acutely aware that everyone around her is comfort someone else.  Only she is alone.
Back at the wheel, BERNIE is turning right onto an unlit highway, his single headlight stabbing weakly at the stor while his useless wipers clatter loudly and the engine ch farts... misses.
I'm late already!  Don't quit on me now, for Chrissake!  This ain't the time! The engine struggles, continues.

Come on, come on ! The engine surges to life again... then begins to throb w downright vigor. BERNIE frowns.  It's getting louder. AND LOUDER!  AND LOUDER!  IT'S ROARING. BERNIE'S eyes bug with the realization that either he's a to take off... OR THAT ISN'T HIS ENGINE THUNDERING, THUND A great shadow blurs in the rain ahead. BERNIE brakes hard, skidding, sliding wildly.
BERNIE skids to a halt, eyes shut tight to prevent himsel dying. But he's not dead.  He opens his eyes.  Stares out the windshield. A blank wall greets him, bouncing back his headlights in of rain.
Now what?

BERNIE gets out of his car.  Everything is spooky quiet. The tail section of a huge aircraft blocks the road direc in front of Bernie's car.  He skidded to a stop two feet of ramming the twenty-five foot high vertical fin.  The r of the craft is sprawled off the low bridge and into the lost for the most part in the darkness. Suddenly, a VOICE calls out... from somewhere forward alo fuselage.

Hey!  Help!  Somebody!  Help. BERNIE frowns.  Helping is not his instinct.  Approaching edge of the bridge, he peers into the darkness. The plane is corkscrewed through the bridge at such a fre angle that the tail rear doors are wedged shut by the met super-structure, the wing exits are blocked by the up-ben stubs, and the right forward doors are canted hopelessly the sky while the left exit is partially jammed in the mu the river bank in three feet of water.
Please!  Help us.  We're stuck. Hello!  Anybody!
Whatsa problem, pal?

Engulfed in darkness except for strings of floor lights l to the exits, the cabin is a confusion of GROANS, COUGHS, and the piercing WAIL of a screaming BABY.  The floor lig seem to be on the walls, high on one side and low on the as the cabin is dramatically canted, making movement alon aisles nearly impossible. LESLIE, battered from the impact, her uniform torn, is struggling to open the forward emergency exit.  Angled do the door will only open six inches before being blocked b Water pours in around her ankles as she shoves furiously.
